div.p: >> Joyce Farrell: Hi.
This is Joyce Farrell.
Let's talk about data types.

There are data types in every
computer programming language

because a data type defines what
values can be stored in an item,

how much memory is allocated
for the item, and what kinds

of operations can be
performed on the item.
In every programming language,

there are at least
two broad data types.
Numeric data is numbers.
Numeric data can hold digits.

It optionally can hold a
plus or minus sign in front

of the number to indicate
positive or negative.

Perhaps there can be a decimal
point and decimal places,

but there's no other punctuation
allowed in numeric data.

No dollar signs,
percent signs, or commas.

The other broad type
of data is string data.

Just about anything can be
contained in string data as long

as it's enclosed
in quotation marks.

There can be letters,
digits, punctuation, spaces,

anything as long as it's
within quotation marks.

Let's look at the data down the
left-hand column of this table,

and try to identify each piece
of data as either numeric

or string or neither
and illegal.
For example, 14?
That's numeric data.
That's a number.

Ninety-eight point six
contains a decimal point.
That's numeric data.

Joe in quotes is
valid string data.

String data is often
something like a first name,
a last name, a city, or a state.
Negative 3, valid numeric data.

How about 2,000 with
a comma in it?

At first, that looks
like numeric data,

but numeric data cannot have
punctuation such as a comma.

Therefore 2,000 with a
comma in it is illegal.
How about 58 in quotes?

Fifty-eight might look
like numeric data,

but if it's in quotes,
it's a string.
A hundred dollars?

Seems to be numeric, but numeric
data cannot have a dollar sign,
so a hundred dollars is illegal.

What do you think about a
hundred dollars in quotes?

Anything in quotes
is a valid string.

So, negative 25 in
quotes? If you said string,
you're absolutely right.
And 44 Pine Lane in quotes?

It has digits, it has
spaces, it has letters.
It is a valid string.
Numeric data.
Again, digits,

maybe plus or minus,
maybe decimal point.
String in double quotes.

Any digits that are
in combination

with other characters that
are not inside quotes,

those pieces of data
are illegal.
Why are there data types?

A data type defines what values
can be stored in an item.

7, 70, minus 7,
7.77 are all numeric.

Book in quotes, 234 in
quotes, Hello Sam in quotes,
those are all strings.

A data type tells you how
much memory is allocated
for the item.

This differs between programming
languages, but for example,

in some languages, a number like
7 might be stored in four bytes

of memory, but a string
like book might be stored
in 16 bytes of memory.

A data type also
tells you what kinds

of operations are
allowed with the data.

If you put a plus sign
between numeric items,

that always creates an
arithmetic expression
that performs addition.
And the value of 7 plus 2 is 9.

If you place a plus
between two strings,

in many programming languages,
that concatenates the strings.

It means adds them end
to end, and the result

of book plus keeper
is bookkeeper.

How about the string
7 plus the string 2?

They're strings, so
they're concatenated,

and the result is
the string 72.
In every programming language,

two numeric values
can be subtracted.

Seven minus 2, that
expression has the value 5.

But in most programming
languages, book minus keeper,

minus is not defined for string
values, and that's illegal

and will cause an
error in your program.
That's a summary of data types.
Thanks for watching.
[ Silence ]
